Do not select Gram stain to diagnose gonorrheal cervicitis.
Test for chlamydia, syphilis, and HIV infection in patients with gonorrhea.

If concurrent chlamydial infection has not been excluded with molecular testing, treat all forms of gonococcal infection with parenteral ceftriaxone and oral doxycycline (preferred) or oral azithromycin (if pregnant). Treat epididymitis with ceftriaxone and doxycycline if infection is most likely caused by chlamydia, gonorrhea, or both. Treat epididymitis with ceftriaxone plus levofloxacin in sexually active patients who are also at risk for infection with enteric organisms (insertive anal intercourse). Levofloxacin monotherapy is recommended for epididymitis treatment if infection is most likely caused by enteric organisms (older men) alone and gonorrhea has been ruled out.
Do not select fluoroquinolones to treat gonorrhea because of antibiotic resistance.
